Question_1.Context: The study focused on the interaction between Pseudomonas lurida and Arthrobotrys oligospora in inducing trap formation.
Question_1.Question: What is the main resource for controlling nematodes mentioned in the study?
Question_1.Source: The biocontrol of PPNs has been extensively researched because it has few negative environmental impacts. Nematode-trapping fungi (NTF) form diverse special traps to capture nematodes through mycelium specialization, such as three-dimensional networks, adhesive knobs, and constricting rings etc. It is one of the ideal materials for studying the biocontrol of nematodes.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the metabolites of Pseudomonas lurida and their effect on inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_2.Question: What was the mutant strain of Pseudomonas lurida constructed in the study?
Question_2.Source: A mutant strain P. lurida araC‑PoprL with abundant secondary metabolites was constructed, and 19 metabolites (1–19) including a new compound, 1,1‑dimethyl‑ 1,3,4,9‑tetrahydropyrano[3,4‑b]indole‑3‑carboxylic acid (1), were isolated and identified.

Question_3.Context: The study explored the activity of isolated metabolites from Pseudomonas lurida in inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_3.Question: Which compound exhibited good induction activity for trap formation in A. oligospora?
Question_3.Source: All isolated compounds were tested for their inducing activity for trap formation in A. oligospora. The results showed that compound 1-methylhydantoin (9) had good induction activity, but other metabolites had no obvious activity.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the metabolites of Pseudomonas lurida and their effect on inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_4.Question: What was the new compound identified from the extract of P. lurida araC-PoprL?
Question_4.Source: Nineteen metabolites, including one new compound, were identified from P. lurida araC-PoprL. Compound 1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9-tetrahydropyrano[3,4-b]indole-3-carboxylic acid (1) was a new compound.

Question_5.Context: The study focused on the interaction between Pseudomonas lurida and Arthrobotrys oligospora in inducing trap formation.
Question_5.Question: What is the AraC family representative of in bacteria?
Question_5.Source: The AraC family of transcriptional regulator is representative of globally regulated genes that have been studied early and are widely distributed in a variety of bacteria. The members of this family can regulate the metabolism of bacteria, for example, the gapR gene could regulate glucose metabolism in Streptomyces aureofaciens by controlling the expression of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.

Question_6.Context: The study explored the metabolites of Pseudomonas lurida and their impact on trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_6.Question: What was the main control method for plant parasitic nematodes mentioned in the study?
Question_6.Source: At present, the main control methods for hazard caused by PPNs can be divided into chemical, physical, agricultural, and biological control. The biocontrol of PPNs has been extensively researched because it has few negative environmental impacts.

Question_7.Context: The study investigated the metabolites of Pseudomonas lurida and their effect on inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_7.Question: What was the strain used to induce trap formation in A. oligospora?
Question_7.Source: Pseudomonas lurida can induce the formation of traps in A. oligospora.

Question_8.Context: The study explored the activity of isolated metabolites from Pseudomonas lurida in inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_8.Question: Which compound was reported to have cytotoxicity and antibacterial activity?
Question_8.Source: Compounds 7, 11, and 19 were reported to have cytotoxicity and antibacterial activity. Cyclo-(Pro-Leu) (11) has the activity of killing M. incognita.

Question_9.Context: The study focused on the interaction between Pseudomonas lurida and Arthrobotrys oligospora in inducing trap formation.
Question_9.Question: What is the role of nematode-trapping fungi in regulating nematode dynamics in soils?
Question_9.Source: NTF, as natural enemies of nematodes, are ideal materials for controlling nematodes. Many researchers have focused on inducing NTF to produce traps through external factors, thus enhancing their ability to capture nematodes.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the metabolites of Pseudomonas lurida and their effect on inducing trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora.
Question_10.Question: What is the potential of P. lurida in controlling nematodes?
Question_10.Source: The bacteria and their metabolites with inducing activity in traps formation of NTF provide resources for the development of new biocontrol agents.
